The effect of Zn(EH)2, Cd(EH)2 and Hg(EH)2 (EH is 2-ethylhexanoate) on cumene oxidation has been established. The use of these catalysts will make it possible to solve a number of tasks that are relevant for cumene oxidation running under industrial conditions, namely: 1) the task of reducing the oxidation time to achieve the required cumene conversion; 2) the task of increasing cumene conversion regardless of the stage of oxidation compared to non-catalytic oxidation (this will reduce the consumption of the recycle stream in the industrial process); 3) the task of accelerating cumene oxidation even in the absence of an initiator at the initial moment of time; 4) the task of maintaining the selectivity of the process even in the late stages of oxidation at a relatively low concentration of the catalyst. The most appropriate catalyst for industrial use is Cd(EH)2 because ROOH·Cd(EH)2 intermediate adduct decomposes most rapidly into free radicals. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Cumene oxidation Kinetic study Non-transition metal catalyst Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates as catalysts 1 Introduction Despite the concern of researchers about the strong oxidizing ability of cumene hydroperoxide (due to which there is a likelihood of ignition at industrial facilities [1]), the demand for it has increased greatly over the past 20 years [2,3]. In industry, cumene hydroperoxide is used: 1) as an initiator for radical polymerization of dienes and cross-linking of sulfide rubbers [4]; 2) as an initiator for radical-chain cumene oxidation in the production of phenol and acetone (that is, in the Hock process [5]); 3) to obtain dicumyl peroxide [3]. In addition, the propylene oxide obtaining by epoxidation of propylene with cumene hydroperoxide [6] began to actively displace the traditional method of propylene oxide obtaining – propylene hydrochlorination [7]. The reason is the negative effect of chlorohydrin on the environment, an intermediate species of propylene hydrochlorination. Therefore, at all recently built Sumitomo Chemical plants, cumene hydroperoxide is used to obtain propylene oxide [8]. This decision is also motivated by the fact that the obtaining of propylene oxide by use of cumene hydroperoxide is “waste-free”, since the resulting by-product (dimethylphenylcarbinol) is easily hydrogenated to form cumene [6,7]. Cumene, in turn, is oxidized by atmospheric oxygen to form cumene hydroperoxide. The cumene oxidation process in this chain of transformations will have a dominant effect, since this process is characterized by: 1) a low value of cumene conversion, since the selectivity of the process decreases with an increase of cumene conversion [9]; 2) accumulation of phenol as an oxidation inhibitor [10]; 3) special safety requirements due to the possible accumulation of oxygen in a reactor [11] and a large amount of heat generated during cumene oxidation [12]. Therefore, the focus of researchers is on intensification of cumene oxidation due to: 1) physical phenomena; 2) improvement of the design of cumene oxidation reactor; 3) usage of various catalysts. It was shown in work [13] that magnetic fields can accelerate the oxidation of hydrocarbons by increasing the rate of chain initiation and decreasing the rate of chain termination. An increase of cumene conversion during its oxidation was observed in sonochemical reactors using ultrasonic waves compared to conditions without ultrasound waves [14]. At present, the kinetics of photooxidation [15] and the role of heterogeneous photocatalysis [16] during cumene oxidation have been studied in detail. However, the results of the study [16] put a doubt about the applicability of photocatalysis for the industrial cumene oxidation, since acetophenone and CO2 were obtained in work [16] instead of cumene hydroperoxide. The design of cumene oxidation reactor can be improved by the following: 1) search for optimal points of air and feed stock supply (direct-flow or counter-flow reactor [17]); 2) installation of air and feed stock distributors (plate, flow mixer, chimney for air recirculation inside the reactor [18]); 3) transition to a cascade of reactors [19]. The use of the above is usually limited by economic factors such as capital costs for equipment and operating costs [20]. The effect of catalysts during cumene oxidation is to increase the rate of individual reactions (either chain initiation or chain propagation reactions), which ultimately leads to an increase of the rate of cumene hydroperoxide accumulation. For instance, copper-based catalysts containing 1,10-phenanthroline [21] and catalysts based on gold and silver nanoparticles [22] accelerate chain initiation reactions. In work [23], the cumene oxidation is catalyzed by a copper-based complex containing a pyridine-imine-chelate ligand and having, according to the authors, an oxygen-activating effect, which promotes the acceleration of chain propagation reactions with participation of oxygen. Most of the catalysts for cumene oxidation are transition metals species, where the chain initiation occurs with the interchange participation of the reduced and oxidized forms of the metal ion in the redox scheme [24,25]. There are many examples of the use of transition metal species as catalysts during cumene oxidation. For instance, in [26,27], catalysis by iron species was investigated. Relatively high values of cumene conversion (44.2%) at a high selectivity (93.2%) were obtained by catalysis with copper-based nanoparticles [28]. Recently, the results of catalysis by metal-organic frameworks based on various transition metals have been published [29–31]. It was established that the most promising is a metal-organic framework based on cobalt [30]. High values of cumene conversion were achieved when a catalytic complex based on ruthenium was used [32]. The catalytic abilities of ionic liquids based on imidazolium [33,34], carbon nanotubes [35–37] and N-hydroxyphthalimide [27,38–40] also deserve special attention. The use of these catalysts allows to run cumene oxidation at relatively low temperatures (353 K [35,38], 363 K [33]), which reduces the risk of uncontrolled autooxidative effect in the industrial process (cumene hydroperoxide is both a product and an initiator of cumene oxidation). However, the time of reaching cumene conversion of 15–20% at such temperatures is rather long (up to 9 h [33]), which ultimately increases the capital costs of the oxidation reactor. None of the mentioned catalysts found application in the industrial cumene oxidation [9]. There are many reasons for this, one of them is the high catalytic activity of transition metals. The rate of catalytic decomposition of initiator (cumene hydroperoxide) is much higher than the rate of its thermal decomposition [24]. As a result, the cumene oxidation in the presence of a transition metal compound as a catalyst runs with high heat release. Obviously, a question of controllability of such a highly exothermic process arises in industry [11]. The above motivates researchers to make a search for new catalysts capable to initiate cumene oxidation with a lower activity than species of transition metals (to reduce the intensity of heat release), but with high selectivity maintaining during the entire cumene oxidation, which is also one of the key factors for ways to optimize industrial reactors for cumene oxidation [20]. For instance, in [41] it was shown that the use of non-transition metals species (magnesium and zinc 2-ethylhexanoates) as catalysts promotes “soft” initiation of cumene oxidation, which increases selectivity at deep stages of the process. At the same time, despite such a number of studies of catalytic cumene oxidation, proper attention has not been paid to catalysts based on metals of zinc subgroup. There are several reasons for the lack of interest among researchers in catalysts based on metals of zinc subgroup: 1) it has been experimentally proved that zinc-based catalytic powders promote the formation of phenols (inhibitors of cumene oxidation) by oxidizing benzene [42]; 2) metals of zinc subgroup have been classified as external-transition metals for many years [43]; 3) due to the fact that metals of zinc subgroup do not have the ability to valence transformations, it is obvious that the catalytic ability of these metals, if any, will be noticeably lower than that of transition metals [24]. However, in recent years it has been shown that: 1) in modern industrial processes of cumene oxidation to cumene hydroperoxide, benzene in the composition of raw materials (commercial cumene) is present in small quantities [20]; having a low concentration, benzene cannot have any effect on cumene oxidation; 2) zinc, cadmium and mercury should be classified as base block metals and not as non-transition metals [44]; 3) metals that are uncapable to valence transformations can catalyze cumene oxidation through the formation of metal complexes [24,45,46]. In this regard, it is topical that the experimentally determination of catalytic capabilities of catalysts based on metals of zinc subgroup and the determination of the prospects for using these catalysts in industrial reactors of cumene oxidation to cumene hydroperoxide, became the purpose of this work. The most suitable way to achieve this purpose is to simulate the kinetics of cumene oxidation, since a comprehensive experimental and theoretical study has an advantage over only an experimental study. The kinetic model makes it possible to assess the degree of participation of Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates at any stage of the process, which means to quite accurately establish the “life cycle” of difficultly fixed intermediate adducts. In our previous work [47], we developed a general kinetic model for cumene oxidation and cumene hydroperoxide decomposition in the presence of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate as a catalyst (see Supplementary data S1). The model from [47] in its simplified form was used in this work to carry out computational experiments. 2 Experimental part There are enough experimental data about the noncatalytic cumene oxidation under laboratory conditions. The work [48] is considered to be a fundamental work, since the expressions obtained in [48] for calculating the rate of chemical reactions and experimental data formed the basis of complex kinetic models [49–51]. That is why in this work we use the experimental data from [48] as independent data. The authors of this work consider it important to also present some experimental results from work [47] in this work, so that the readers have the opportunity to compare the results of computational and laboratory experiments. These data were obtained relying not only on the personal authors experience [20,41,51–53], but also on the experience of previous works on the experimental study of cumene oxidation [22,24,54–56]. The established practice of experimental studies of cumene oxidation and cumene hydroperoxide decomposition is given in [47]. 2.1 Substances The following substances were used in the experiments: 1) cumene produced by PJSC Kazanorgsintez; 2) cumene hydroperoxide produced by PJSC Kazanorgsintez (22 mass% of cumene hydroperoxide and 78 mass% of cumene); cumene hydroperoxide was subjected to distillation and achieved 99% of the mass concentration; a feed stock with the required content of cumene hydroperoxide was obtained by mixing cumene and distilled cumene hydroperoxide in the required proportion; 3) molecular oxygen as an oxidizing agent (the nitrogen-oxygen mixture purification was carried out using desiccants with silica gel and NaOH), the nitrogen-oxygen mixture consists of 21 vol% oxygen and 79 vol% nitrogen; 4) Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates as catalysts during cumene oxidation and cumene hydroperoxide decomposition (catalysts were prepared by the interaction of 2-ethylhexanoic acid and the corresponding metal oxides in boiling benzene); the resulting water was separated in a Dean-Stark apparatus; benzene was separated from the resulting solutions by distillation; after distilling benzene, the catalyst solutions were washed with distilled water and saturated NaHCO3 solution); 5) chlorobenzene as a solvent in cumene hydroperoxide decomposition. 2.2 The catalytic oxidation of cumene The kinetics of cumene oxidation to cumene hydroperoxide in the presence of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate was studied in a column reactor at temperature 383 K. The studies were carried out using the unit shown in Fig. 1. The reactor (item 1) of 36 mm diameter and 500 mm high is made of heat-resistant glass and equipped a cooling system (item 2) for vapor condensation. The nitrogen-oxygen mixture supplied for oxidation is sucked in through a mechanical impurities filter (item 4) and with the help of a compressor (item 5) is fed into the drying system (item 6), where moisture and all kinds of other species (organic vapors) contained in the nitrogen-oxygen mixture. The nitrogen-oxygen mixture was distributed in the reactor volume in form of bubbles using a distribution grid (item 7) with 1 mm diameter holes. The heating coil (item 8), insulated with asbestos paper provides uniform heating of the reactor (item 1). The temperature of the reaction mixture was controlled within ± 0.5 K using thermostat (item TIC) and contact thermometer (item TT). After supplying water to the cooling system (item 2) and turning on the heating of the reactor (item 1), nitrogen-oxygen mixture was supplied to the reactor. Cumene ([RH]0 = 6.44 mol/L, hereinafter, the designation in square brackets means the concentration of species, index 0 refers to the initial time of the process) or a feed stock (cumene [RH]0 = 6.44 mol/L with the addition of cumene hydroperoxide [ROOH]0 = 0.143 mol/L, initial concentration of other species are 0) with added Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate (catalyst concentrations varied and amounted to 3, 5, 7.5 mmol/L) was introduced through the funnel (item 9) when the valve was opened (item 10). Upon reaching the temperature of 383 K, the flow rate of nitrogen-oxygen mixture was increased to 0.6 L/min, providing a guaranteed process flow in the kinetic region. This moment was recorded as the beginning of the experiment. At specified time intervals, the oxidate samples were taken by sampling valve (item 3) for quantitative analysis of the cumene hydroperoxide content and other oxidation products. By the end of the experiment, the cooled oxidate was poured by valve (item 11) into the flask and the complete analysis was performed to determine its composition (quantitative analysis). 2.3 The catalytic decomposition of cumene hydroperoxide The kinetics of cumene hydroperoxide decomposition in the presence of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate was studied by the ampoule method. For this, firstly the solutions of cumene hydroperoxide and catalyst in chlorobenzene were prepared (initial concentration of cumene hydroperoxide [ROOH]0 = 1 and 1.5 mol/L and catalyst [Cat]0 = 5 mmol/L). Each solution was poured into several glass ampoules with a volume of 7 ml (1.5 ml of solution in each ampoule). Then the ampoules were sealed and immersed in a thermostat heated to a predetermined temperature. At certain time intervals, one by one ampoule was removed, and the reaction was quickly stopped by placing the ampoule in a glass with ice water. Then the ampoules were opened and the cumene hydroperoxide concentration was determined. 2.4 Analysis methods Determination of cumene hydroperoxide concentration was performed by iodometric titration with sensitivity to I2 concentration of 10-5 mol/L [57]. The products of cumene oxidation (in a column reactor) and cumene hydroperoxide decomposition (in ampules) were analyzed by gas-liquid chromatography (HP-6890 Series GC System; capillary column with a polar phase; carrier is the polyethylene glycol) with sensitivity of 10-7 mol/L. 3 Kinetic model The kinetic model, created by us in [47] according to the mass action law, in its simplified form (see Supplementary data S1) is based on the kinetic scheme, which consists of the following reactions (1)-(36): Table Formation of intermediate adducts: RH + Cat ⟶ k 1 RH ⋅ Cat , (1) ROOH + Cat ⟶ ⟵ k 2 ′ k 2 ROOH ⋅ Cat , (2) ROH + Cat ⟶ ⟵ k 3 ′ k 3 ROH ⋅ Cat , (3) HC ( O ) H + Cat ⟶ k 4 HC ( O ) H ⋅ Cat . It should be noted that this kinetic scheme is valid not only for cumene oxidation, but also for cumene hydroperoxide decomposition (provided that the rate of oxygen concentration change in the reaction mixture due to its dissolution in it is zero). In the experiments carried out in this work, the chromatogram showed no response to formic acid and methanol. The authors attribute this to the imperfection of the cooling system, which does not allow condensing volatile products in sufficient quantities to detect them on the chromatogram (insufficient heat transfer driving force when using cooled water to achieve complete condensation of volatile oxidation products). Nevertheless, these species are present in cumene oxidation kinetic scheme. Evidence for the formation of highly volatile oxidation products was obtained by assessing the carbon balance of cumene oxidation process. To do this, the comparison was made for the total concentration of carbon atom contained in all species at the initial time of cumene oxidation and after 6 h of oxidation. The carbon balance results are presented in Supplementary data S2 (see Tables A2–A4). This carbon balance showed a decrease in the total carbon atom concentration in the reaction mixture during cumene oxidation in the presence of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate. The difference in the initial and final concentrations of carbon atom in the reaction mixture is associated with the formation of volatile hydrocarbons during cumene oxidation, which was not experimentally detected. In [47], we considered the issues of kinetic modeling and the probable mechanism of cumene oxidation and cumene hydroperoxide decomposition in the presence of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate as a catalyst, and the analysis of sensitivity of the model to changes in its coefficients. The main problem solved in this article is to explain the catalytic capabilities of catalysts based on metals of zinc subgroup and to determine the prospects for using these catalysts in industrial reactors for cumene oxidation to cumene hydroperoxide using a kinetic model. A comparison of the experimental data and the data calculated by the kinetic model from [47] is shown in Figs. 2–5 and Table 1. Wherein, the temperature dependencies of reaction rate coefficients (Arrhenius equations) from [47] were used in calculations by the kinetic model. The parameters of these temperature dependencies: A is a preexponential factor and E is a reaction activation energy, were determined in [47] from the solution of the inverse kinetic problem (see Table A1 in Supplementary data S1). The experimental data are described by a kinetic model within the average relative experimental error (25%). This condition is satisfied by entire ranges of coefficient values, which are named the uncertainty regions. Some of these regions (the most interesting in terms of interpreting their shape) are given in Supplementary data S3. The shape of two-dimensional uncertainty regions of the values of reaction rate coefficients indicates the role that this or that reaction plays in cumene oxidation. For instance, two-dimensional uncertainty regions for the rate coefficients of reactions (2) and (2') in the case of cumene oxidation in the presence of Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate have boundaries in the shape of rays emanating from the point k2 = 0 and k 2 ′ = 0 (see Supplementary data S3, Figs. A3a and A4a). Throughout these rays, the condition k 2 / k 2 ′ = const is satisfied. The chemical meaning of this mathematical observation is that k 2 / k 2 ′ is the equilibrium coefficient of the reversible reaction (2). It is logical that the non-individual values of k 2 and k 2 ′ do affect the kinetics of cumene oxidation. The equilibrium coefficient k 2 / k 2 ′ affect the kinetics of cumene oxidation on which the adduct ROOH ⋅ Cat concentration depends. The two-dimensional uncertainty region for the rate coefficients of reactions (3) and (27) in the case of cumene oxidation in the presence of Zn 2-ethylhexanoate has the shape of hyperbola (see Supplementary data S3, Fig. A2f). This means that the kinetics of cumene oxidation in the presence of Zn 2-ethylhexanoate as a catalyst is affected not by the individual values of the coefficients k 3 and k 27 , but by their multiplication k 3 ∙ k 27 . This is due to the fact that the concentration of ROH ⋅ Cat adduct is proportional to the equilibrium coefficient k 3 / k 3 ′ , that is, proportional k3, and the decomposition rate of ROH ⋅ Cat , which determines the decomposition rate of ROH , is proportional to both k 27 and ROH ⋅ Cat concentration. Therefore, the ROH decomposition rate is proportional to the multiplication of coefficients k 3 ∙ k 27 . For a similar reason, the kinetics of cumene oxidation without catalysts is affected not by individual values of the coefficients k 33 and k 34 , but by their multiplication k 33 ∙ k 34 (see Supplementary data S3, Fig. A1h). 4 Results and discussion The Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates accelerate cumene hydroperoxide decomposition (Fig. 5) it can be seen from the results of an experimental study of the kinetics of cumene hydroperoxide decomposition. These data once again confirm the participation of intermediate ROOH ⋅ Cat adduct in the formation of free radicals according to reaction (8). Moreover, from the values of the activation energy for reactions (7) and (8) (see Table A1 in Supplementary data S1) found as a result of solving the inverse kinetic problem, it is evident that the decomposition of ROOH ⋅ Cat adduct by reaction (8) requires four times less energy than the decomposition by reaction (7). Consequently, the introduction of catalysts must cause an increase of the rate of cumene hydroperoxide accumulation during cumene oxidation, since the formed free radicals, according to reaction (8), activate chain propagation reactions with participation of oxygen (autoinitiation effect). Experimental studies of the kinetics of cumene oxidation product accumulation clearly show that with an increase of the concentration of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate, the accumulation rate of not only cumene hydroperoxide, but also other cumene oxidation products does increase (Fig. 4). This fact indicates to the effect of Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates not only on the chain initiation reactions, but also on the chain propagation and termination reactions. This means that Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates, provided that the optimal concentrations of these catalysts are selected to maintain selectivity, have good prerequisites for their use during cumene oxidation. It should be noted here that we are not the first ones who noticed that 2-ethylhexanoic acid salts (2-ethylhexanoates) can be used in radical chain processes. The effect of 2-ethylhexanoic acid salts on the decomposition of hydrocarbon hydroperoxides (for example, tetralin hydroperoxide) was demonstrated as far back as late 1950 s [58]. In [59], the use of Sn 2-ethylhexanoate led to a significant lengthening of the polydimethylsiloxane chain even in the absence of a cross-linking agent. Then Kricheldorf and Mahler showed that Sn 2-ethylhexanoate can be used in bulk polymerization of hexamethylene carbonate as an initiator [60]. Salts of 2-ethylhexanoic acid have found application in radical oligomerization and polymerization. This was facilitated by several very important studies: 1) oxidation and oligomerization of ethyl linoleate [61]; 2) polymerization of 1,3-butadiene [62]; 3) polymerization of ethylene with the predominant formation of 1-hexene (transformation of polymerization into trimerization) [63]. The uniqueness of 2-ethylhexanoic acid salts is that they are easily soluble in petroleum solvents [64]. The use of 2-ethylhexanoic acid salts in industrial cumene oxidation can also be successful, because heterogeneous catalysts cannot be used in existing industrial reactors without additional costs [9]. However, the issue of the need and applicability of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate from the point of view of technological criteria in industrial reactors for cumene oxidation is still open. Recent works on the study of cumene oxidation [9–11,65] provide comprehensive data for the current state of this production. In our previous work [20], we showed that process optimization consists of finding a compromise between the values of cumene conversion, selectivity, and total annual costs per unit of produced cumene hydroperoxide. In general, carrying out the cumene oxidation under industrial conditions is complicated by several factors [20]: 1) there is a need in large reactors; the share of capital costs for the oxidation reactor can be up to 70% of the total capital costs, taking into account the stripping column for separating the oxidation products from cumene and heat exchangers to maintain the temperature; 2) high values of the flow rate of the recycle stream due to the low cumene conversion (under some conditions, the flow rate of the recycle stream may be an order of magnitude higher than the flow rate of fresh cumene); 3) the constant need of cumene hydroperoxide in the recycle stream (cumene hydroperoxide is required as initiator). Therefore, every catalyst proposed to researchers must able to solve all these problems, namely: 1) to reduce the time of oxidation to achieve the required cumene conversion; 2) to increase the cumene conversion compared to noncatalytic cumene oxidation to reduce the recycle stream; 3) to have a possibility to accelerate the accumulation of cumene hydroperoxide, even without initiator. In order to clearly show that Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates have all the above-mentioned qualities, we carried out the computational experiments ( Figs. 6 and 7). Moreover, in each of these computational experiments, two cases of the initial concentration of species in the reaction mixture were considered. The first case is that there are no oxidation products (including, in the absence of an initiator) at the initial moment of time of cumene oxidation. The second case is that the oxidation products are present (including in the presence of non-target by-products) at the initial moment of time of cumene oxidation. This case will make it possible to evaluate the effect of Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates under industrial conditions, where the fresh cumene stream is mixed with the recycle stream before entering the reactor of cumene oxidation. In addition, in [20], we noted that the optimal value of cumene conversion from the point of view of minimum total annual costs lies in the range of 25–30%. Therefore, in these computational experiments, we will evaluate our catalysts until 30% cumene conversion is reached. Fig. 6 shows the dependencies of cumene conversion versus time during cumene oxidation: 1) without cumene hydroperoxide as an initiator at the initial moment of time (Fig. 6 a); 2) under industrial conditions (the initial concentrations of species correspond to the composition of the feed stock from [20]), when the feed stock contains not only cumene hydroperoxide, but also by-products (Fig. 6 b). The required cumene conversion in these two cases is achieved during minimum 10 h. If we consider the case of using 1 mmol/L Cd 2-ethylhexanoate, then we can see that the cumene oxidation is accelerated 1.5 times in case (a) and 1.25 times in case (b) compared to noncatalytic oxidation. That is, the use of this catalyst: 1) will reduce the oxidation time to achieve the required cumene conversion; 2) will increase cumene conversion at any stage of oxidation in comparison with noncatalytic oxidation, thereby reducing the flow rate of the recycle stream in industrial processes; 3) will make it possible to accelerate cumene oxidation even without initiator at the initial moment of time. It should be highlighted that most of the existing catalysts also solve all of the above problems of industrial cumene oxidation. But, despite all this, the industrial cumene oxidation is being maintained without catalysts. The reason for this is that the existing catalysts lose their ability to selectively oxidize cumene at a later stage of the process. In the case of use Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates during cumene oxidation, we also observe a decrease in selectivity as the cumene conversion increases (Fig. 7). However, as we can see, a significant decrease in selectivity is characteristic only at the late stages of cumene oxidation, when cumene conversion exceeds 50%. Moreover, it can be noted that Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates perform better, both in the absence of initiator (Fig. 7 c, e) and in the presence of by-products (Fig. 7 d, f) than Zn 2-ethylhexanoate (Fig. 7 a, b). Dependencies of selectivity versus cumene conversion for cumene oxidation in the presence of any of the studied catalysts at a relatively low catalyst concentration (Zn(EH)2 ≤ 1 mmol/L, Cd(EH)2 ≤ 2.5 mmol/L, Hg(EH)2 ≤ 2.5 mmol/L) are almost identical to the selectivity versus cumene conversion for the process in the absence of a catalyst (Fig. 7). In other cases (at high catalyst concentrations), the cumene oxidation in the presence of catalysts is much less selective than the cumene oxidation in the absence of catalyst. It is obvious that decrease of selectivity at the later stages of cumene oxidation is associated with a noticeable increase in the rate of formation of by-products. The time dependences of the rates of formation of cumene oxidation products in the presence of Cd 2-ethylhexanoate were calculated by us using a kinetic model ( Fig. 8). It should be noted that the forms of kinetic curves of the formation of cumene oxidation products in the presence of Zn or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate are similar to the forms of the corresponding kinetic curves of the formation of cumene oxidation products in the presence of Cd 2-ethylhexanoate (Fig. 8). In the initial section of time dependence of the rate of target product formation (cumene hydroperoxide) during catalytic oxidation, the rate is relatively high (the higher the rate, the higher the catalyst concentration) – see Fig. 8 a. Thereafter, with an increase of oxidation time, the rate of cumene hydroperoxide formation decreases. At relatively low catalyst concentrations, another maximum appears on the time dependence of the rate of cumene hydroperoxide formation. Calculations show that the rates of reactions (19) and (20) are orders of magnitude lower than the rate of reaction (11), therefore the rate of cumene hydroperoxide formation (Fig. 8 a) is equal to the rate of reaction (11) ( Fig. 9 a). In addition, to confirm that the rates of reactions (19) and (20) are orders of magnitude lower than the rate of reaction (11), we carried out computational experiments to establish the quantitative values of all the rates of ROO• radicals consumption during cumene oxidation in the presence of Cd(EH)2 ( Fig. 10); according to the kinetic scheme, cumene hydroperoxide ROO• is consumed by reactions (11), (16), (19), (20), (22), (23), (24)). Fig. 10 shows that even if we sum ROO• consumption rates over reactions (16), (19), (20), (22), (23), (24), the total rate will still be an order of magnitude lower than reaction rate (11). This fact is another proof that the rate of ROOH cumene hydroperoxide formation mainly depends on the rate of reaction (11). In addition, Figs. 11 and 12 show the time dependences of the accumulation and consumption rates of ROOH cumene hydroperoxide during cumene oxidation in the presence of Cd(EH)2 as a catalyst. Fig. 11 shows that the rate of ROOH accumulation is mainly composed of the rates of three reactions (2'), (11), (25): Fig. 12 shows that the rate of ROOH consumption depends on reaction (2). If we take into account that reaction (2') is inverse with respect to (2), then it can be understood that the accumulation rate of cumene hydroperoxide mainly depends on reaction (11), since cumene, reacting with ROO•, additionally gives the radical R•, which, in turn, recombines with •OOH to form ROOH. The rate of cumene hydroperoxide formation is determined by the concentrations of RH (Fig. 9 c) and ROO• (Fig. 9 d). The decrease of the rate of cumene hydroperoxide formation at the end of its time course (Fig. 9 a) is associated with a decrease of cumene concentration RH (Fig. 9 c), and the beginning of this curve is determined by the concentration of ROO• (Fig. 9 d). Of all the reaction rates for the formation of ROO•, the rate of reaction (10) is the most important (Fig. 9 b). This rate is equal to the rate of reaction (11) (Fig. 9 a). This result is quite logical, since these are the main chain propagation reactions where ROO• and R• radicals pass into each other. The concentrations of ROO• (Fig. 9 d) and R• (Fig. 9 e) are in a state of dynamic equilibrium. This leads to two conclusions: 1) reactions (10) and (11) cannot be used to explain the change of ROO• concentration under conditions of constant [O2] (the ratio of the rates of these reactions simply establishes the proportion between the concentrations of ROO• and R•); 2) to explain the time dependence of the concentration of ROO• it is necessary to consider the rates of formation of ROO• and R• together. From these figures, the following conclusion can be made: the first maximum on the time dependence of the rate of cumene hydroperoxide formation is associated with an increased concentration of radicals ROO• (Fig. 9 d), formed from radicals R• (Fig. 9 e) (and this is logical, the first maximum cannot be associated with anything else, since at the initial moment of time the reaction mixture contains only RH, catalyst and oxygen dissolved from the nitrogen-oxygen mixture). The second maximum is associated with the autoinitiation effect. An increase of ROO• concentration (Fig. 9 d) results in a second maximum on the time course of the rate of cumene hydroperoxide formation (Fig. 9 a). Overall, the dimethylphenylcarbinol ROH has the highest rate of formation of all byproducts. This increase of rate is carried out by reaction (32), it is the main reason for the decrease of selectivity with increasing catalyst concentration. In addition, detailed kinetic analysis showed that at relatively low concentrations of Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates, the cumene oxidation can be carried out so that at the initial stages of the process (up to 15 h), the loss of selectivity is compensated by increase of the rate of cumene hydroperoxide formation. In fact, this means that the most expedient for industrial use is the catalyst that will increase the rate of cumene hydroperoxide formation most of all. In order to determine the most suitable catalyst, time dependencies of cumene hydroperoxide concentration were obtained during cumene oxidation in the presence of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate (initial concentrations of all catalysts are 1 mmol/L) ( Fig. 13). The analysis of these dependencies shows that it is reasonable to use Cd 2-ethylhexanoate, since the rate of target product accumulation (cumene hydroperoxide) in this case is maximum both in the absence of oxidation products, including the initiator (Fig. 13 а), and with by-products of oxidation process in the reaction mixture at the initial moment of time (Fig. 13 b). In [41], it was stated that the rate of cumene hydroperoxide accumulation in the presence of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate must crucially depend on the concentration of intermediate adducts. The calculations we made in this work did show that the rate of cumene hydroperoxide accumulation depends on the concentration of ROOH⋅Cat intermediate adduct ( Fig. 14 a). Fig. 14 a shows that the concentration of ROOH ⋅ Cat intermediate adducts at the initial stages of cumene oxidation (characterized by the appearance of free radicals) increases in the series Cd > Hg > Zn, as does the concentration of cumene hydroperoxide (Fig. 13). Moreover, it can be seen from Fig. 14 b that the concentrations of RH ⋅ Cat adducts in all cases prevail over the concentrations of ROOH ⋅ Cat adducts (Fig. 14 a), but have a different sequence (Zn > Cd > Hg). This fact clearly shows that the rate of cumene hydroperoxide accumulation in the oxidation of cumene in the presence of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate depends only on the ability of these catalysts to form a particular ROOH ⋅ Cat intermediate adduct. The decomposition of ROOH ⋅ Cat intermediate adduct leads to the formation of new radicals, and the decomposition of RH ⋅ Cat intermediate adduct occurs under the action of radicals already present in the reaction system, which does not increase the total concentration of radicals and the rate of the entire process. Eventually, it can be say that due to the decomposition of ROOH ⋅ Cat intermediate adduct the number of RO• and ROO• radicals increases, which are involved in rapid cyclic transformations in radical chain process of cumene oxidation ( Fig. 15). In these transformations the RO• and ROO• radicals react with the initial cumene RH and formation ROH and ROOH. That is why the use of these catalysts leads to a decrease the selectivity at late stages of oxidation. In this case, there is a shift towards the predominant formation of by-products. Further, the use of additional agents, to reduce the decomposition of ROOH ⋅ Cat towards RO•, will help to avoid such a shift and increase not only the cumene conversion during its oxidation, but also the selectivity of ROOH formation. According to the kinetic scheme, Cd 2-ethylhexanoate catalyst (the most suitable catalyst for industrial use) is reduced by reactions (2'), (3'), (6), (8), (27), (28), (30), (32). In addition, reaction (36) is included in the kinetic scheme, which formally shows a decrease in the catalyst concentration due to its transition to an inactive form (thermal decomposition, loss of catalyst selectivity, pollution, poisoning, etc.). Fig. 16 shows that the rate of these reactions is several orders of magnitude higher than the rate of the deactivation reaction (36), which once again clearly demonstrates the role of the catalyst: an increase of RO• and ROO• radicals concentration (they participate in chain propagation reactions in the radical chain cumene oxidation) as a result of decomposition. In our opinion, the obtained series of catalytic activity can be explained by the properties of metals of the zinc subgroup. When discussing the formation and decomposition of ROOH ⋅ Cat intermediate adduct, the atomic properties of metals were considered ( Table 2). Table 2 shows that the thermodynamic characteristics of the formation and decomposition of ROOH ⋅ Cat intermediate adduct (∆H, ∆S, E, etc.) largely determine the highest catalytic activity of Cd 2-ethylhexanoate, since all these characteristics pass through a minimum in the series Zn-Cd-Hg. The irregularity of changes of properties in the Zn-Cd-Hg series is well known and is explained by the easy deformability of the d10-electron shells of elements of the zinc subgroup. As a result, an additional polarization effect arises, which leads to the possibility of the formation of covalent bonds. The deformability of the d10-shell from top to bottom in the subgroup increases [66], which leads to the ease of formation of covalent bonds of Hg. However, Zn also easily forms such bonds (organozinc compounds). In this respect, Cd is inferior to both Zn and Hg (dip in covalence) due to the irregular change in the polarizing action in Zn-Cd-Hg series. The ability of atoms to displace the electron shells of other atoms, molecules, ions (polarizing effect) by the action of their own electronic field has a different nature for Zn and Hg. Since the atomic radius grows in Zn-Cd-Hg series, Zn must have the maximum polarizing effect, but at the same time, the additional polarization effect sharply increases in the same series. For Cd, the polarizing effect is minimal due to the overlapping of two regularities [67]: 1) an increase of the polarizing effect with an increase of the deformability of d10-electron shell in Zn < Cd < Hg series; 2) an increase of the polarizing effect due to a decrease of the atomic radius in Hg < Cd < Zn series. The nonmonotonic growth of the polarizing effect of Zn subgroup leads to a peculiar course of change not only in covalence, but also in other properties of atoms and their compounds (Table 2). Thus, it is precisely the minimal polarizing effect that causes a “drop out” of Cd from the “normal” row of elements the IIb subgroup. In connection with the above, the compounds Zn and Hg should have the highest catalytic activity during hydroperoxides decomposition. However, it was established in this work that Cd 2-ethylhexaonate decomposes cumene hydroperoxide at the highest rate, and this process requires the lowest activation energy among the metals in question (Table 2). In [67], a lower stability of Cd intermediate adducts is noted in comparison to analogous Zn and Hg intermediate adducts. Indeed, Fig. 14 а, shows that ROOH ⋅ Cat intermediate adduct in the case of Cd 2-ethylhexanoate decomposes most rapidly into free radicals, while having the lowest values of the enthalpy and entropy of adduct formation (Table 2). 5 Conclusion The effect of Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates on cumene oxidation has been experimentally established. It was shown that the catalytic abilities of Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates during cumene oxidation are related to their ability to accelerate cumene hydroperoxide decomposition with the formation of free radicals. Based on calculations using a kinetic model, it was shown that the use of the considered catalysts: 1) will reduce the oxidation time to achieve the required cumene conversion; 2) will increase the cumene conversion regardless of the oxidation stage compared to non-catalytic oxidation, thereby reducing the volume flow rate of the recycle stream in industrial processes; 3) make it possible to accelerate cumene oxidation even without initiator at the initial moment of time; 4) will not lose selectivity even at late stages of relatively low catalyst concentrations (Zn(EH)2 ≤ 1 mmol/L, Cd(EH)2 ≤ 2.5 mmol/L, Hg(EH)2 ≤ 2.5 mmol/L). The rate of cumene hydroperoxide accumulation during cumene oxidation in the presence of Zn, Cd or Hg 2-ethylhexanoate depends only on the ability of these catalysts to form a particular ROOH ⋅ Cat intermediate adduct. It was determined that the most appropriate catalyst for industrial use is Cd 2-ethylhexanoate. Since the rate of accumulation of the target product in this case will be maximum both in the absence of oxidation products, including an initiator, and in the presence of oxidation by-products in the reaction mixture at the initial moment of time. The high catalytic ability in the case of Cd 2-ethylhexanoate is explained by the fact that. intermediate adduct decomposes most rapidly into free radicals, while having the lowest values of the enthalpy and entropy of the adduct formation in comparison to the cases of intermediate adducts formation with participation of Zn and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates. The main imperfection of the homogeneous catalysts proposed in this work is attributed with the difficulty of their separation from the process products. We assume that Cd 2-ethylhexanoate will be separated at the last stage of the technological production of phenol and acetone – at the stage of separation of phenol from bottom products (tar) by distillation. The phenol vapors are taken from the top of the distillation column, which are then condensed. The Cd 2-ethylhexanoate, due to its lower fugacity, will accumulate in the bottom of the column along with the tar. In addition, we assume that Cd 2-ethylhexanoate will be inert after cumene oxidation process and up to its separation from phenol. It will not prevent the following: 1) decomposition of cumene hydroperoxide into phenol and acetone; 2) separation of the products of phenol and acetone production in distillation columns. In the future, the authors want to perform a few studies aimed at creating a procedure for recovery of Cd 2-ethylhexanoate from the tar, since this task is not trivial. However, even now it can be said that: 1) bottom products obtained in relatively small quantities, including catalysts, can be separated in small units and without large capital expenditure; 2) the use of Cd 2-ethylhexanoate in the recommended amount (1 mmol/L) would not harm the final commercial phenol, even if the catalyst accumulates on the upper contact devices of the distillation column (according to our calculations, the phenol concentration in this case will be 99.96 mass% at a characteristic for cumene method of phenol obtaining, the concentration is 99.70–99.99 mass%). coredata.dc:description: The effect of Zn(EH)2, Cd(EH)2 and Hg(EH)2 (EH is 2-ethylhexanoate) on cumene oxidation has been established. The use of these catalysts will make it possible to solve a number of tasks that are relevant for cumene oxidation running under industrial conditions, namely: 1) the task of reducing the oxidation time to achieve the required cumene conversion; 2) the task of increasing cumene conversion regardless of the stage of oxidation compared to non-catalytic oxidation (this will reduce the consumption of the recycle stream in the industrial process); 3) the task of accelerating cumene oxidation even in the absence of an initiator at the initial moment of time; 4) the task of maintaining the selectivity of the process even in the late stages of oxidation at a relatively low concentration of the catalyst. The most appropriate catalyst for industrial use is Cd(EH)2 because ROOH·Cd(EH)2 intermediate adduct decomposes most rapidly into free radicals.
coredata.dc:title: Prospects for the use of Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates as catalysts for cumene oxidation

dcterms:subject.$: Zn, Cd and Hg 2-ethylhexanoates as catalysts
